title: Smartgoat
author: Smartgoat
content: Africa is blessed with natural resources. But are under the mis-management by there corrupt leaders who claims to be democratic. but their for personal benefits. let's look at president Ali Bongo and family, which was said to have been in power for over 53years. but was taken over by military, as a case study.should Africans agree for military takeover of all the Africa nations for proper restoration of African glory. or they should remean in corrupt democratic government . what are your say on this......

comments.body: Quote from: Smartgoat on September 03, 2023, 07:42:51 PMshould Africans agree for military takeover of all the Africa nations for proper restoration of African glory. or they should remean in corrupt democratic government . what are your say on this......I have heard the saying that the worse kind of democracy is better than the best military rule but African leaders were or are leading the people of Africa with dishonesty, impunity to the law which is very important. comments.author: Hispo
comments.body: I think we already have several threads around here in the Politics and Society section which are mostly about this subject.Anyways, I am not in favor of military takes over. Perhaps, I could do an exception if those coups were to get rid of an anti democratic or corrupt regime and they called for free and fair elections to take place within a limited window of time, but does not seem to be the case.This rather something which is taking place to replace some regimes with more openly authoritarian rulers which are pretty much in favor of Russian an Chinese intervention in the continent and against the west.

comments.author: sesterceshop
comments.body: I think that relying on the military to solve problems isn't the best strategy. They need governments that truly come from the people's choice. Governments that are fair and not tangled up in corruption or favoritism. They shouldn't be using the military to kick out leaders who were elected by the people. Instead, African leaders should team up and encourage democracy and good, honest leadership across the continent.

I believe every country had it's peculiarities in terms of the events that led to the ousting of the erstwhile democratic governments. Like in the case of Niger, what led to the military takeover wss driving by three factors. Firstly, even though Niger has several foreign (USA, France) military forces and bases situated in the country, yet Niger is faced with the invasion of insurgent groups such as the Al-Qaeda, Boko Haram, etc which has resulted to thousands of deaths and displaced homes which has been seemingly neglected by the government. Secondly, the ECOWAS, like in most west African countries, haven't made as much efforts as it should as a body in terms of intervention programmes yet they go about bossing to restore Bazoum. Lastly, which is the least of all is that the former president Bazoum had an identity crisis in the last election where he was labeled to have foreign interests above the national interest due to his Arab origin.When you compared that to what happened to Ali Bongo of Gabon, it's quite a different scenario, in Gabon, it was more of electoral malpractices and imposition. They president was widely rejected by the citizens yet had it's way through to win at the polls. That brought about several agitations that led to the coup. Also realize that the economic downturn in the country amidst the natural endowment in the small country has led it to several outcries. And the list goes on.It's just a case of the world power tussle between the UN Permanent Security Council Members.

comments.author: Alpha Marine
comments.body: What these countries lack is a system. They don't practice democracy. They just say they do. Military rule won't solve anything. Some might say it would make it worse but I doubt that, it would just be the same old story. What these countries need is a system. One person can't hold all the power. There should be ways to make Democracy powerful the way it is in developed countries. A country with a poor political system would always have a poor economic system thereby making every other sector in the country poor. People are allowed to do whatever they want in these countries if they have the power, but it should be so. A lack of a system makes it very easy for people to abuse their powers and this goes on at all levels of government. The police and other security agencies abuse their power, and the judiciary, legislature, and executive all abuse their powers.  When a system is in place these people would be checked and they can't get away with these things.

comments.author: Hispo
comments.body: Quote from: Alpha Marine on September 15, 2023, 11:47:47 AMWhat these countries lack is a system. They don't practice democracy. They just say they do. Military rule won't solve anything. Some might say it would make it worse but I doubt that, it would just be the same old story. What these countries need is a system. One person can't hold all the power. There should be ways to make Democracy powerful the way it is in developed countries. A country with a poor political system would always have a poor economic system thereby making every other sector in the country poor. People are allowed to do whatever they want in these countries if they have the power, but it should be so. A lack of a system makes it very easy for people to abuse their powers and this goes on at all levels of government. The police and other security agencies abuse their power, and the judiciary, legislature, and executive all abuse their powers.  When a system is in place these people would be checked and they can't get away with these things. The system you are talking about for those African countries is called "separation of power". The United States is a good example of how separation of power works, back during the first presidency of Trump he got several of his executive orders blocked by federal judges, and when he wanted to overturn the election results in Georgia they tried to pressure the Secretary of State (the only one with the direct power to recall those results). That is a system where one single person cannot do whatever they desire with their position. However, separation of power can become ineffective if many of those officials which are supposed to be neutral and only obey the constitution fail to their oath and obey lawless orders from a central authority.

comments.author: DeathAngel
comments.body: Africa's issues with corrupt leaders can be attributed to many things. Historical legacies such as colonialism & weak governance structures play a big role. Poverty, lack of accountability & limited access to education & resources can contribute to the problem. To help combat this a multifaceted approach is necessary. Strengthening democratic institutions, promoting transparency & accountability, investing in education & healthcare & fostering economic development can all help tackle corruption. Empowering citizens to participate in decision’making processes & supporting grassroots initiatives are also vital steps towards a more transparent & accountable leadership in Africa.
